articles.headline: A Stealth Tax Subsidy for Business Faces New Scrutiny
articles.snippet: Many companies are borrowing money for projects using tax-exempt bonds called qualified private activity bonds, costing federal taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars.
articles.abstract: Many companies are borrowing money for projects using tax-exempt bonds called qualified private activity bonds, costing federal taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: The last time the nation’s tax code was overhauled, in 1986, Congress tried to end a big corporate giveaway.
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and Louise Story

articles.headline: Justices to Take Up Case on Generic Drug Makers’ Liability
articles.snippet: Karen Bartlett was grievously injured by a mild painkiller, and the Supreme Court will hear arguments this month on whether the maker can be held responsible.
articles.abstract: Karen Bartlett was grievously injured by a mild painkiller, and the Supreme Court will hear arguments this month on whether the maker can be held responsible.
articles.lead_paragraph: The injuries that Karen Bartlett suffered after taking a mild pain pill are enough to make anyone squeamish.

articles.headline: Debate Over Guns Now Colors a Buyout Bid
articles.snippet: A deal for the Outdoor Channel has inspired a heated debate about whether a businessman’s ties to Democrats who support stricter gun-control laws will alter programming and scare away advertisers.
articles.abstract: A deal for the Outdoor Channel has inspired a heated debate about whether a businessman’s ties to Democrats who support stricter gun-control laws will alter programming and scare away advertisers.
articles.lead_paragraph: A takeover. Private equity. Politics. And guns.

articles.headline: F.C.C. Backs Consumers in Unlocking of Cellphones
articles.snippet: The White House and the Federal Communications Commission said consumers should be free to unlock their phones once contracts are satisfied.
articles.abstract: The White House and the Federal Communications Commission said consumers should be free to unlock their phones once contracts are satisfied.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For a decade consumers have been able to keep their cellphone numbers even if they switched their wireless carriers. On Monday, the Obama administration and the Federal Communications Commission said consumers should also be able to switch carriers and keep their actual phones.

articles.headline: Senate Report Said to Fault JPMorgan
articles.snippet: A Congressional investigation could revive questions about the role of senior executives in a $6 billion trading loss at JPMorgan Chase.
articles.abstract: A Congressional investigation could revive questions about the role of senior executives in a $6 billion trading loss at JPMorgan Chase.
articles.lead_paragraph: While a trader known as the “London whale” has come to represent a multibillion-dollar blowup at JPMorgan Chase, Congressional investigators have discovered that the problems involved more senior levels of the nation’s largest bank.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Don’t Touch That Remote: TV Pilots Turn to Net, Not Networks
articles.snippet: More television shows are being produced only for the Internet, circumventing existing distribution channels.
articles.abstract: More television shows are being produced only for the Internet, circumventing existing distribution channels.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the television pilot that Cheyenne Jackson taped recently, he played an aggressive young news anchor whose ascendancy threatened an older colleague. It was a fitting metaphor for the industry itself, because while Mr. Jackson had taped pilots for ABC, NBC and USA before, this was his first time doing one for a new challenger to those alphabet networks: Amazon.com.

articles.headline: Cabinet Picks Could Take On Climate Policy
articles.snippet: In nominating Gina McCarthy to head the E.P.A. and Ernest J. Moniz for the Energy Department, President Obama showed his intent to use all the tools at his disposal to tackle climate change.
articles.abstract: In nominating Gina McCarthy to head the E.P.A. and Ernest J. Moniz for the Energy Department, President Obama showed his intent to use all the tools at his disposal to tackle climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Monday named two people to his cabinet who will be charged with making good on his threat to use the powers of the executive branch to tackle climate change and energy policy if Congress does not act quickly.
articles.byline: By John M. Broder and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: U.S. Disavows 2 Drone Strikes Over Pakistan
articles.snippet: American officials suspect one or possibly both of the strikes were carried out by the Pakistani military and falsely attributed to the C.I.A. to avoid criticism from the Pakistani public.
articles.abstract: American officials suspect one or possibly both of the strikes were carried out by the Pakistani military and falsely attributed to the C.I.A. to avoid criticism from the Pakistani public.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — When news of the two latest drone strikes emerged from Pakistan’s tribal belt in early February, it seemed to be business as usual by the C.I.A.

articles.headline: A Private Boom Amid Detroit’s Public Blight
articles.snippet: Across the country, businesses have recovered while the public sector has struggled, and Detroit may be the most extreme example of a city’s dual fates diverging.
articles.abstract: Across the country, businesses have recovered while the public sector has struggled, and Detroit may be the most extreme example of a city’s dual fates diverging.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Private industry is blooming here, even as the city’s finances have descended into wreckage.

articles.headline: Dancer Held in Acid Attack on Bolshoi Director
articles.snippet: Police officials in Moscow on Tuesday detained a dancer at the Bolshoi Ballet, Pavel Dmitrichenko, in connection with a January acid attack on the company’s artistic director.
articles.abstract: Police officials in Moscow on Tuesday detained a dancer at the Bolshoi Ballet, Pavel Dmitrichenko, in connection with a January acid attack on the company’s artistic director.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Police officials here on Tuesday detained a dancer at the Bolshoi Ballet and two suspected accomplices in connection with an acid attack in January on the company’s artistic director, Sergei Filin, a crime that gripped Moscow and left one of Russia’s most revered institutions in turmoil.

articles.headline: As Fears Recede, Dow Industrials Hit a Milestone
articles.snippet: There are concerns about whether the forces that have driven the market rally — government spending and banner corporate profits — will be sufficient to push it higher.
articles.abstract: There are concerns about whether the forces that have driven the market rally — government spending and banner corporate profits — will be sufficient to push it higher.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economy may be struggling to recover, but by one closely watched measure the fear that not long ago paralyzed the markets has lifted.
